title: Display font for nonprofit newsletter
content:
I’m looking for a display font that conveys the notion of fluid, currents, motion, flow of liquid, etc.

I’m revamping the quarterly print newsletter for a nonprofit devoted to advocacy and research around a neurological condition. The title of the newsletter is still under debate but will be something about flow/current. The organization’s logo uses Optima (not my decision) along with a wave-like graphic.

FYI, in the past we’ve used Slimbach and more recently Minion for the body text of the newsletter; I’m not yet sure if we’ll be changing that too.

I’m clueless when it comes to readable, modern script fonts, so I’m thinking about a really nice italic version of a serif font. Thoughts?

author: Amelia

comments.content:
a really nice italic version of a serif font?

mrs. eaves

hands down.
If you have an interest in scripts, I’d be surprised if [Sudtipos](http://web.archive.org/web/20071223123211/http:/sudtipos.com/home) lets you down.

Makes me think of some of the Storm fonts. Here’s Serapion, Sebastion, and John Sans. Degrees of wavy.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071223123211im_/http:/typophile.com/files/wavy_4142.gif)

auricfuzz, you’re right — Sudtipos totally has my number. Can’t believe I haven’t come across them before.

I’m also digging Sebastian, especially the w’s.

I’ve got a lot more to play with now. Thanks all.
